Analyzing the Impact of Partial Sharing on the Resilience of Online Federated Learning Against Model Poisoning Attacks

Ehsan Lari, , Vinay Chakravarthi Gogineni, ,
Reza Arablouei, and Stefan Werner This work was supported by the Research Council of Norway. Part of this work has been presented to the 2024 IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing (ICASSP), Seoul, South Korea, Apr. 2024 [DOI: 10.1109/ICASSP48485.2024.10447497]. (Corresponding author: Ehsan Lari.)Ehsan Lari and Stefan Werner are with the Department of Electronic Systems, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim 7491, Norway (e-mail: {ehsan.lari, stefan.werner}@ntnu.no). Stefan Werner is also with the Department of Information and Communications Engineering, Aalto University, 00076, Finland.Vinay Chakravarthi Gogineni is with the SDU Applied AI and Data Science, The Maersk Mc-Kinney Moller Institute, Faculty of Engineering, University of Southern Denmark, Odense 5230, Denmark (e-mail: vigo@mmmi.sdu.dk).Reza Arablouei is with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, Pullenvale, QLD 4069, Australia (e-mail: reza.arablouei@csiro.au).
Abstract

We scrutinize the resilience of the partial-sharing online federated learning (PSO-Fed) algorithm against model-poisoning attacks. PSO-Fed reduces the communication load by enabling clients to exchange only a fraction of their model estimates with the server at each update round. Partial sharing of model estimates also enhances the robustness of the algorithm against model-poisoning attacks. To gain better insights into this phenomenon, we analyze the performance of the PSO-Fed algorithm in the presence of Byzantine clients, malicious actors who may subtly tamper with their local models by adding noise before sharing them with the server. Through our analysis, we demonstrate that PSO-Fed maintains convergence in both mean and mean-square senses, even under the strain of model-poisoning attacks. We further derive the theoretical mean square error (MSE) of PSO-Fed, linking it to various parameters such as stepsize, attack probability, number of Byzantine clients, client participation rate, partial-sharing ratio, and noise variance. We also show that there is a non-trivial optimal stepsize for PSO-Fed when faced with model-poisoning attacks. The results of our extensive numerical experiments affirm our theoretical assertions and highlight the superior ability of PSO-Fed to counteract Byzantine attacks, outperforming other related leading algorithms.

Index Terms:
Online federated learning, Byzantine clients, partial-sharing, linear regression, model-poisoning.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [1, 2] is a distributed learning paradigm that enables a network of devices, such as smartphones, internet of things (IoT) nodes, and media streamers, to jointly learn a global model without the need to directly disclose their local raw data to the server or other devices. FL is particularly beneficial when data is distributed across numerous devices, and conducting centralized training by transferring the data to the server is unfeasible or impractical [3, 4]. FL exhibits two key features: the ability to handle heterogeneous data, such as non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) or unbalanced data, and the ability to run on heterogeneous devices that may have limited resources [5, 6, 7].

The communication load in FL refers to the volume of data transmitted between the central server and participating devices during training. It can affect the efficiency and scalability of FL in real-world applications as excessive data transmission may escalate resource usage and the cost associated with training [8, 9, 10]. Several algorithms have been proposed to alleviate the communication load in FL. Among them, sign stochastic gradient descent (SignSGD) [11, 12] utilizes sign-based gradient compressors to lower the communication and computational costs of FL. Compressive sensing FL (CS-Fed) [13] reduces the communication load using 111-bit compressive sensing in analog aggregation transmissions. Quantile sketch FL (QS-Fed) [14] improves communication efficiency by compressing model updates using a count sketch. Online-Fed [15] enhances communication efficiency by engaging only a randomly selected subset of clients to communicate with the server in each iteration. However, the aforementioned works do not consider the potential presence of adversaries within the network who may seek to undermine the learning process. This can be through tampering with message exchanges or intentionally providing corrupted or incorrect information. Factoring in the possibility of malicious clients in the network is an important aspect of developing reliable and robust FL algorithms.

In network environments, Byzantine clients are those that act unpredictably or with malicious intent. Such clients can disrupt normal operations by sending misleading information or not following established protocols. This behavior poses significant risks to the FL process, potentially leading to disruption or degraded performance [16, 17]. Byzantine clients can jeopardize the integrity and reliability of the global model in FL. They may engage in deceptive practices, such as submitting false or inconsistent gradients or model weights during updates, or even initiating denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, all of which can compromise the integrity and effectiveness of the FL process [18, 19, 20]. To mitigate the impact of Byzantine clients in FL, various strategies have been proposed. These include the use of robust aggregate statistics, the assignment of trust scores to individual clients, and the utilization of historical information to recover from Byzantine attacks [21, 22].

Byzantine clients may launch a wide range of adversarial attacks such as data-poisoning, model-poisoning, and label-poisoning [23, 24]. Data-poisoning attacks involve the injection of malicious data into the training dataset [25, 26]. Evasion attacks involve manipulating input data to undermine the generalizability of the learned model while evading detection [27]. Backdoor attacks involve embedding hidden trigger mechanisms within the model that can induce targeted malicious behavior [28]. Inference-time attacks, such as membership inference, aim to uncover whether a specific data point has been used in training, raising privacy concerns [29, 30].

Attacks can also target network infrastructure, such as distributed DoS attacks and man-in-the-middle attacks, disrupting services or intercepting communications [31]. Model-poisoning attacks, where Byzantine clients manipulate model updates during training, are prominent examples [32]. Defense strategies against model-poisoning attacks in FL are reviewed in [32], categorized into evaluation methods for local model updates and aggregation methods for the global model. In evaluation methods, the server examines client submissions without having access to local client data, which poses challenges to their applicability. In aggregation methods, the server adjusts the local model updates based on certain criteria or utilizes relevant statistical methods. Robust aggregation techniques using median or trimmed mean can mitigate the impact of malicious clients on the global model [33]. Blockchain-assisted aggregation schemes can also help cope with network attacks but often incur high communication load or computational complexity [34].

A SignSGD-based communication-efficient FL algorithm has recently been proposed in [35] that exhibits resilience to Byzantine attacks. However, it assumes the consistent participation of all clients in every FL iteration, which may not align with the practical realities of FL, particularly in scenarios where clients (such as mobile or IoT devices) have limited resources in terms of energy or computational capacity. Therefore, there is a notable gap in the current FL research: the need for communication-efficient FL algorithms that are robust against model-poisoning attacks without imposing additional computational burden on clients. Addressing this gap can make FL more accessible and practical for a wider range of devices, especially those with constrained resources, and enhance the robustness and scalability of FL systems in real-world applications.

In this paper, we analyze the performance of the partial-sharing online FL (PSO-Fed) algorithm [9, 8, 36], particularly in the face of Byzantine attacks. Our analysis reveals that partial sharing in online FL, while primarily aimed at enhancing communication efficiency, also offers the added advantage of mitigating the adverse effects of model-poisoning attacks. Through rigorous theoretical analysis, we demonstrate that PSO-Fed can converge in both mean and mean-square senses, even when subjected to model-poisoning attacks. In addition, we derive the theoretical steady-state mean square error (MSE) of PSO-Fed. A key finding of our analysis is the identification of a non-trivial optimal stepsize for PSO-Fed under model-poisoning attacks. Contrary to the common behavior of stochastic gradient descent algorithms where a smaller stepsize often results in enhanced performance, in the case of PSO-Fed under model-poisoning attacks, a smaller stepsize does not automatically equate to better estimation accuracy. This is a departure from the norm observed in gradient-descent-based algorithms, where smaller stepsizes are commonly used to enhance performance, often at the cost of a slower convergence rate. We provide a theoretical calculation of the optimal stepsize. To validate our theoretical insights, we conduct extensive numerical experiments using synthetic non-IID data. The experimental outcomes confirm our theoretical predictions and show that PSO-Fed exhibits greater resilience to Byzantine attacks compared to other state-of-the-art algorithms, including Online-FL, all while avoiding any additional computational overhead.

We organize the remainder of this paper as follows. In section II, we provide an overview of the system model, PSO-Fed algorithm, and model-poisoning attacks. In section III, we evaluate the robustness of PSO-Fed against Byzantine attacks by analyzing its theoretical mean and mean-square convergence. In this section, we also calculate PSO-Fed’s theoretical steady-state MSE and optimal stepsize. In section IV, we verify our theoretical findings through a series of numerical experiments. In these experiments, we evaluate the performance of PSO-Fed under model-poisoning attacks through both theoretical predictions and numerical simulations. Finally, in section V, we present some concluding remarks.

II Preliminaries

In this section, we first describe the considered system model. We then briefly outline the PSO-Fed algorithm [9], which is a communication-efficient variant of the Online-Fed algorithm [15]. Afterward, we define the model-poisoning Byzantine attack within the context of FL and probe its impact on the model update equations of PSO-Fed.

II-A System Model

We consider a network consisting of K𝐾K clients and a central server. At every time instance n𝑛n, each client k𝑘k has access to a data vector 𝐱k,n∈ℝDsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑛superscriptℝ𝐷\mathbf{x}_{k,n}\in\mathbb{R}^{D} and its corresponding response value yk,n∈ℝsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑛ℝy_{k,n}\in\mathbb{R}, which are related via the model

yk,n=𝐰⊺​𝐱k,n+νk,n,subscript𝑦𝑘𝑛superscript𝐰⊺subscript𝐱𝑘𝑛subscript𝜈𝑘𝑛\displaystyle y_{k,n}=\mathbf{w}^{\intercal}\mathbf{x}_{k,n}+\nu_{k,n}, (1)

where the model parameter vector 𝐰∈ℝD𝐰superscriptℝ𝐷\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{D} is collaboratively estimated using the locally stored client data, and νk,nsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑛\nu_{k,n} is the observation noise. We define the global objective function for estimating 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} as

𝒥​(𝐰)=1K​∑k=1K𝒥k​(𝐰)𝒥𝐰1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝒥𝑘𝐰\displaystyle\mathcal{J}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{J}_{k}(\mathbf{w}) (2)

with the local objective function at client k𝑘k being

𝒥k​(𝐰)subscript𝒥𝑘𝐰\displaystyle\mathcal{J}_{k}(\mathbf{w}) =𝔼​[|yk,n−𝐰⊺​𝐱k,n|2].absent𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑛superscript𝐰⊺subscript𝐱𝑘𝑛2\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[|y_{k,n}-\mathbf{w}^{\intercal}\mathbf{x}_{k,n}|^{2}\right]. (3)

The goal is to find the optimal estimate of 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} by minimizing 𝒥​(𝐰)𝒥𝐰\mathcal{J}(\mathbf{w}), i.e., 𝐰⋆=arg⁡min𝐰⁡𝒥​(𝐰)superscript𝐰⋆subscript𝐰𝒥𝐰\mathbf{w}^{\star}=\arg\min_{{\mathbf{w}}}\mathcal{J}(\mathbf{w}), albeit, in a distributed fashion via FL.

II-B PSO-Fed

In PSO-Fed, to reduce the communication load, the server only sends a portion of the global model estimate to the clients. Similarly, the clients transmit parts of their local model estimates to the server. The model parameters exchanged between client k𝑘k and the server at iteration n𝑛n are specified using a diagonal selection matrix with M𝑀M ones, which is denoted by 𝐒k,n∈ℝD×Dsubscript𝐒𝑘𝑛superscriptℝ𝐷𝐷{\bf S}_{k,n}\in\mathbb{R}^{D\times D}. The positions of the ones on the diagonal determine which model parameters are shared with the server at each iteration. They can be selected arbitrarily or in a round-robin fashion as in [37, 38] such that the model parameters are exchanged between each client and the server, on average, M𝑀M times in every D𝐷D iterations. Therefore, the probability of any model parameter being shared with the server in any iteration is pe=M/Dsubscript𝑝𝑒𝑀𝐷p_{e}=M/D.

Using the selection matrices 𝐒k,nsubscript𝐒𝑘𝑛{\bf S}_{k,n}, the recursive update equations of PSO-Fed, that iteratively minimize (2) through FL, are expressed as [8]

ϵk,nsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘𝑛\displaystyle\epsilon_{k,n} =yk,n−[𝐒k,n​𝐰n+(𝐈D−𝐒k,n)​𝐰k,n]⊺​𝐱k,nabsentsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑛superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐒𝑘𝑛subscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝐈𝐷subscript𝐒𝑘𝑛subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛⊺subscript𝐱𝑘𝑛\displaystyle=y_{k,n}-\left[\mathbf{S}_{k,n}\mathbf{w}_{n}+\left(\mathbf{I}_{D}-\mathbf{S}_{k,n}\right)\mathbf{w}_{k,n}\right]^{\intercal}\mathbf{x}_{k,n} (4a)
𝐰k,n+1subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{k,n+1} =𝐒k,n​𝐰n+(𝐈D−𝐒k,n)​𝐰k,n+μ​𝐱k,n​ϵk,nabsentsubscript𝐒𝑘𝑛subscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝐈𝐷subscript𝐒𝑘𝑛subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛𝜇subscript𝐱𝑘𝑛subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘𝑛\displaystyle=\mathbf{S}_{k,n}\mathbf{w}_{n}+\left(\mathbf{I}_{D}-\mathbf{S}_{k,n}\right)\mathbf{w}_{k,n}+\mu\hskip 0.56905pt\mathbf{x}_{k,n}\epsilon_{k,n} (4b)
𝐰n+1subscript𝐰𝑛1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{n+1} =1|𝒮n|​∑k∈𝒮n[𝐒k,n+1​𝐰k,n+1+(𝐈D−𝐒k,n+1)​𝐰n],absent1subscript𝒮𝑛subscript𝑘subscript𝒮𝑛delimited-[]subscript𝐒𝑘𝑛1subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛1subscript𝐈𝐷subscript𝐒𝑘𝑛1subscript𝐰𝑛\displaystyle=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{n}|}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{n}}\left[\mathbf{S}_{k,n+1}{\mathbf{w}}_{k,n+1}+\left(\mathbf{I}_{D}-\mathbf{S}_{k,n+1}\right)\mathbf{w}_{n}\right], (4c)

where 𝐰k,nsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑛\mathbf{w}_{k,n} is the local model estimate at client k𝑘k and iteration n𝑛n, 𝐰nsubscript𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}_{n} is the global model estimate at iteration n𝑛n, 𝐈Dsubscript𝐈𝐷\mathbf{I}_{D} is the D×D𝐷𝐷D\times D identity matrix, μ𝜇\mu is the stepsize controlling the convergence rate and steady-state performance, 𝒮nsubscript𝒮𝑛\mathcal{S}_{n} denotes the set of client selected at iteration n𝑛n, and |𝒮n|subscript𝒮𝑛|\mathcal{S}_{n}| denotes the number of the selected clients in each iteration.

II-C Model-Poisoning Attacks

We denote the set of potential Byzantine clients within the network as 𝒮Bsubscript𝒮𝐵\mathcal{S}_{B}. To represent the presence or absence of Byzantine behavior in a client, we use the indicator variable βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}, where βk=1subscript𝛽𝑘1\beta_{k}=1 indicates that client k𝑘k belongs to the set 𝒮Bsubscript𝒮𝐵\mathcal{S}_{B} (i.e., is a Byzantine client), and βk=0subscript𝛽𝑘0\beta_{k}=0 otherwise. The total number of Byzantine clients in the network is denoted by |𝒮B|subscript𝒮𝐵|\mathcal{S}_{B}|. These Byzantine clients seek to poison the global model (i.e., undermine its accuracy) by sporadically sending corrupt local model estimates to the server. We assume that the Byzantine clients possess the accurate local model estimates. More specifically, we consider a scenario where, in each iteration, every Byzantine client deliberately corrupts its local model estimate by perturbing it, before sending it to the server. This corruption is conducted with a certain probability of attack, denoted by pasubscript𝑝𝑎p_{a}. Consequently, we represent the model update shared by any Byzantine client as [39]

𝐰k,n′={𝐰k,n+𝜹k,nwith probability pa𝐰k,nwith probability 1−pa,subscriptsuperscript𝐰′𝑘𝑛casessubscript𝐰𝑘𝑛subscript𝜹𝑘𝑛with probability pasubscript𝐰𝑘𝑛with probability 1−pa{\mathbf{w}}^{\prime}_{k,n}=\begin{cases}\mathbf{w}_{k,n}+\bm{\delta}_{k,n}&\text{with probability $p_{a}$}\\ \mathbf{w}_{k,n}&\text{with probability $1-p_{a}$},\end{cases} (5)

where 𝜹k,n∈ℝDsubscript𝜹𝑘𝑛superscriptℝ𝐷\bm{\delta}_{k,n}\in\mathbb{R}^{D} denotes the perturbation signal associated with the attack. Typically, this perturbation is zero-mean white Gaussian noise, characterized as 𝜹k,n∼𝒩​(𝟎,σB2​𝐈D)similar-tosubscript𝜹𝑘𝑛𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵2subscript𝐈𝐷\bm{\delta}_{k,n}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},\sigma_{B}^{2}\mathbf{I}_{D}) [39].

The probability of a Byzantine client corrupting its local estimate can be modeled using a Bernoulli random variable τk,nsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛\tau_{k,n}. This variable takes the value of 111 with probability pasubscript𝑝𝑎p_{a} indicating the occurrence of an attack, and 00 otherwise. Hence, given that each Byzantine client transmits a corrupted local model estimate to the server with a probability of pasubscript𝑝𝑎p_{a} when selected by the server, in scenarios where Byzantine clients are present in the network, the global model update of PSO-Fed, (4c), can be rewritten as

𝐰n+1=1|𝒮n|​∑k∈𝒮n[𝐒k,n+1​𝐰k,n+1′+(𝐈D−𝐒k,n+1)​𝐰n]subscript𝐰𝑛11subscript𝒮𝑛subscript𝑘subscript𝒮𝑛delimited-[]subscript𝐒𝑘𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝐰′𝑘𝑛1subscript𝐈𝐷subscript𝐒𝑘𝑛1subscript𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}_{n+1}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{n}|}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{n}}\left[\mathbf{S}_{k,n+1}{\mathbf{w}}^{\prime}_{k,n+1}+\left(\mathbf{I}_{D}-\mathbf{S}_{k,n+1}\right)\mathbf{w}_{n}\right]

where

𝐰k,n+1′=𝐰k,n+1+βk​τk,n​𝜹k,n+1.subscriptsuperscript𝐰′𝑘𝑛1subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛1subscript𝛽𝑘subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝜹𝑘𝑛1{\mathbf{w}}^{\prime}_{k,n+1}=\mathbf{w}_{k,n+1}+\beta_{k}\tau_{k,n}\bm{\delta}_{k,n+1}.

III Comprehensive Analysis

In this section, we evaluate the robustness of PSO-Fed against Byzantine attacks by analyzing its theoretical mean and mean-square convergence and predicting its steady-state MSE and optimal stepsize.

(10)

To make the analysis tractable, we adopt the following commonly used assumptions.

A1: The input vectors of each client, 𝐱k,nsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑛{\mathbf{x}}_{k,n}, originate from a wide-sense stationary multivariate random process characterized by the covariance matrix 𝐑k=𝔼​[𝐱k,n​𝐱k,n⊺]subscript𝐑𝑘𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐱𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑛⊺{\bf R}_{k}=\mathbb{E}[{\mathbf{x}}_{k,n}{\mathbf{x}}_{k,n}^{\intercal}].

A2: The observation noise, νk,nsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑛\nu_{k,n}, and perturbation signal, 𝜹k,nsubscript𝜹𝑘𝑛\bm{\delta}_{k,n}, both follow identical and independent distributions. They are also independent of all other stochastic variables.

A3: The selection matrices, 𝐒k,nsubscript𝐒𝑘𝑛\mathbf{S}_{k,n}, of all clients and iterations are independent of each other.

III-A Mean Convergence

Let us define the deviation (coefficient-error) vector as 𝐰~e,n=𝐰e⋆−𝐰e,nsubscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑒⋆subscript𝐰𝑒𝑛\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n}={\bf w}_{e}^{\star}-{\bf w}_{e,n}. Since 𝓑n+1subscript𝓑𝑛1\bm{\mathcal{B}}_{n+1} and 𝓐nsubscript𝓐𝑛\bm{\mathcal{A}}_{n} are block right-stochastic, i.e., their block rows add up to identity matrix, we have 𝓑n+1​𝐰e⋆=𝓐n​𝐰e⋆=𝐰e⋆subscript𝓑𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑒⋆subscript𝓐𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑒⋆superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑒⋆\bm{\mathcal{B}}_{n+1}{\bf w}_{e}^{\star}=\bm{\mathcal{A}}_{n}{\bf w}_{e}^{\star}={\bf w}_{e}^{\star}. Therefore, considering (8) and the definition of 𝐰~e,nsubscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n}, we get

𝐰~e,n+1=subscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛1absent\displaystyle\widetilde{{\bf w}}_{e,n+1}= 𝓑n+1​(𝐈−μ​𝐗n​𝐗n⊺)​𝓐n​𝐰~e,n−μ​𝓑n+1​𝐗n​𝝂e,nsubscript𝓑𝑛1𝐈𝜇subscript𝐗𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑛⊺subscript𝓐𝑛subscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛𝜇subscript𝓑𝑛1subscript𝐗𝑛subscript𝝂𝑒𝑛\displaystyle\bm{\mathcal{B}}_{n+1}\big{(}\mathbf{I}-\mu{\mathbf{X}}_{n}{\mathbf{X}}_{n}^{\intercal}\big{)}\bm{\mathcal{A}}_{n}\widetilde{{\bf w}}_{e,n}-\mu\bm{\mathcal{B}}_{n+1}{\mathbf{X}}_{n}\bm{\nu}_{e,n}
−\displaystyle- 𝓒n+1​𝐁𝐓n​𝜹e,n+1.subscript𝓒𝑛1subscript𝐁𝐓𝑛subscript𝜹𝑒𝑛1\displaystyle{\bm{\mathcal{C}}}_{n+1}\mathbf{B}\mathbf{T}_{n}\bm{\delta}_{e,n+1}. (11)

Taking the expected value of both sides of (III-A) and under assumptions A1-A3, we obtain

𝔼​[𝐰~e,n+1]=𝔼​[𝓑n+1]​(𝐈−μ​𝓡)​𝔼​[𝓐n]​𝔼​[𝐰~e,n],𝔼delimited-[]subscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛1𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝓑𝑛1𝐈𝜇𝓡𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝓐𝑛𝔼delimited-[]subscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{{\bf w}}_{e,n+1}]=\mathbb{E}[\bm{\mathcal{B}}_{n+1}]\big{(}\mathbf{I}-\mu\bm{\mathcal{R}}\big{)}\mathbb{E}[\bm{\mathcal{A}}_{n}]\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{{\bf w}}_{e,n}], (12)

where

𝓡=bdiag​{𝟎,𝐑1,𝐑2,⋯,𝐑K}.𝓡bdiag0subscript𝐑1subscript𝐑2⋯subscript𝐑𝐾\bm{\mathcal{R}}=\mathrm{bdiag}\{{\bf 0},{\bf R}_{1},{\bf R}_{2},\cdots,{\bf R}_{K}\}.

The mean convergence of PSO-Fed is guaranteed if ‖(𝐈−μ​𝓡)‖<1norm𝐈𝜇𝓡1\|\left(\mathbf{I}-\mu\bm{\mathcal{R}}\right)\|<1 or equivalently ‖1−μ​λi​(𝐑k)‖<1norm1𝜇subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝐑𝑘1\|1-\mu\lambda_{i}\left({\bf R}_{k}\right)\|<1 ∀k,ifor-all𝑘𝑖\forall k,i. Here, ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| is any matrix norm and λi​(⋅)subscript𝜆𝑖⋅\lambda_{i}\left(\cdot\right) denotes the i𝑖ith eigenvalue of its matrix argument. Consequently, PSO-Fed converges in the mean sense, even amidst the presence of Byzantine clients, as long as the stepsize μ𝜇\mu is appropriately chosen to satisfy

0<μ<2maxi,k⁡{λi​(𝐑k)}.0𝜇2subscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝐑𝑘0<\mu<\frac{2}{\max_{i,k}\{\lambda_{i}\left({\bf R}_{k}\right)\}}. (13)

In other terms, PSO-Fed is unbiased, even under model-poisoning attacks.

As n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty, (III-B) converges provided that the spectral radius of 𝓕𝓕\bm{\mathcal{F}} is smaller than one, i.e., ρ​(𝓕⊺)=ρ​(𝓕)<1𝜌superscript𝓕⊺𝜌𝓕1\rho({\bm{\mathcal{F}}}^{\intercal})=\rho({\bm{\mathcal{F}}})<1. Considering [41, Theorem 2] and defining

the spectral radius of 𝓕𝓕\bm{\mathcal{F}} is smaller than one when

where λmax​(⋅)subscript𝜆⋅\lambda_{\max}(\cdot) denotes the largest eigenvalue of its matrix argument. We denote the upper bound of (30) as μmaxsubscript𝜇\mu_{\max}. Thus, when (30) holds, PSO-Fed converges in the mean-square sense and has a bounded steady-state MSD, even when facing Byzantine attacks.

The partial sharing of model parameters, scheduling of clients, statistics of input data, and value of stepsize impact the first and second terms on the RHS of (III-C), ℰϕsubscriptℰbold-italic-ϕ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}} and ℰ𝝎subscriptℰ𝝎\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}}. The observation noise influences the first and third terms, ℰϕsubscriptℰbold-italic-ϕ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}} and ℰ𝚯subscriptℰ𝚯\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\Theta}}, with the latter term being solely due to this noise. Moreover, the effect of model-poisoning attacks by Byzantine clients on the steady-state MSE of PSO-Fed is confined to the second term, ℰ𝝎subscriptℰ𝝎\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}}, which is induced by these attacks.

Remark 1: Considering (III-B) and the calculation of 𝓠𝓒subscript𝓠𝓒{\bm{\mathcal{Q}}}_{\bm{\mathcal{C}}} in Appendix C, both partial sharing and client scheduling have a diminishing effect on 𝝎𝝎\bm{\omega}. The lower the probability of sharing each entry of the model parameter vector, pe=MDsubscript𝑝𝑒𝑀𝐷p_{e}=\frac{M}{D}, the smaller the entries of 𝝎𝝎\bm{\omega} are. Therefore, (III-C) suggests that partial sharing can indeed endow online FL with enhanced resilience to model-poisoning attacks. However, partial sharing also affects ℰϕsubscriptℰbold-italic-ϕ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}} and increases its value as shown in [8, Fig. 1(a)]. This makes it hard to straightforwardly determine the overall impact of partial sharing on the steady-state MSE of PSO-Fed in scenarios involving model-poisoning attacks, by only analyzing (III-C). To gain deeper insights and validate these theoretical predictions, we undertake comprehensive simulations in section IV.

III-D Optimal Stepsize

In the absence of model-poisoning attacks where ℰ𝝎=0subscriptℰ𝝎0\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}}=0, ℰℰ\mathcal{E} is a monotonically increasing function of the stepsize μ𝜇\mu, given (30) is satisfied. However, under model-poisoning attacks, the existence of ℰ𝝎subscriptℰ𝝎\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}} disrupts this monotonicity. It amplifies ℰℰ\mathcal{E} for smaller values of μ𝜇\mu and shifts the point of minimal ℰℰ\mathcal{E} from μ=0𝜇0\mu=0 to a larger μ>0𝜇0\mu>0. Consequently, this leads to the emergence of a non-trivial optimal stepsize that results in the minimum ℰℰ\mathcal{E} when facing model-poisoning attacks. We denote this optimal stepsize as μ∗superscript𝜇\mu^{*}.

Assuming (30) is satisfied hence ρ​(𝓕⊺)<1𝜌superscript𝓕⊺1\rho(\bm{\mathcal{F}}^{\intercal})<1, approximating (𝐈−𝓕⊺)−1superscript𝐈superscript𝓕⊺1\big{(}\mathbf{I}-\bm{\mathcal{F}}^{\intercal}\big{)}^{-1} with its corresponding J𝐽J-term truncated Neumann series [42, Eq. (186)] gives

(𝐈−𝓕⊺)−1≈∑j=0J(𝓕⊺)j.superscript𝐈superscript𝓕⊺1superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝐽superscriptsuperscript𝓕⊺𝑗\big{(}\mathbf{I}-\bm{\mathcal{F}}^{\intercal}\big{)}^{-1}\approx\sum_{j=0}^{J}\left(\bm{\mathcal{F}}^{\intercal}\right)^{j}. (35)

We consider J≥3𝐽3J\geq 3. Moreover, for simplicity, we rewrite (18) as

𝓕⊺=𝐀0−μ​𝐀1+μ2​𝐀2,superscript𝓕⊺subscript𝐀0𝜇subscript𝐀1superscript𝜇2subscript𝐀2\displaystyle\bm{\mathcal{F}}^{\intercal}=\mathbf{A}_{0}-\mu\mathbf{A}_{1}+\mu^{2}\mathbf{A}_{2},

by defining 𝐀0=𝓠𝓐⊺​𝓠𝓑⊺subscript𝐀0superscriptsubscript𝓠𝓐⊺superscriptsubscript𝓠𝓑⊺\mathbf{A}_{0}={\bm{\mathcal{Q}}}_{\bm{\mathcal{A}}}^{\intercal}{\bm{\mathcal{Q}}}_{\bm{\mathcal{B}}}^{\intercal}, 𝐀1=𝓠𝓐⊺​𝓚​𝓠𝓑⊺subscript𝐀1superscriptsubscript𝓠𝓐⊺𝓚superscriptsubscript𝓠𝓑⊺\mathbf{A}_{1}={\bm{\mathcal{Q}}}_{\bm{\mathcal{A}}}^{\intercal}\bm{\mathcal{K}}{\bm{\mathcal{Q}}}_{\bm{\mathcal{B}}}^{\intercal}, and 𝐀2=𝓠𝓐⊺​𝓗​𝓠𝓑⊺subscript𝐀2superscriptsubscript𝓠𝓐⊺𝓗superscriptsubscript𝓠𝓑⊺\mathbf{A}_{2}={\bm{\mathcal{Q}}}_{\bm{\mathcal{A}}}^{\intercal}\bm{\mathcal{H}}{\bm{\mathcal{Q}}}_{\bm{\mathcal{B}}}^{\intercal}. Using (35) in (III-C), we have

Since a valid stepsize is typically much smaller than one, we can further approximate ℰℰ\mathcal{E} by excluding terms beyond μ2superscript𝜇2\mu^{2} as

Differentiating ℰℰ\mathcal{E} in (36) with respect to μ𝜇\mu, setting the derivative equal to zero, and solving for μ𝜇\mu yields the approximate optimal stepsize as

μ∗≈𝝎⊺​𝐁1,J​𝓠𝓐⊺​bvec​{𝓡}2​(ϕ⊺​𝐁0,J+𝝎⊺​𝐁2,J)​𝓠𝓐⊺​bvec​{𝓡}.superscript𝜇superscript𝝎⊺subscript𝐁1𝐽superscriptsubscript𝓠𝓐⊺bvec𝓡2superscriptbold-italic-ϕ⊺subscript𝐁0𝐽superscript𝝎⊺subscript𝐁2𝐽superscriptsubscript𝓠𝓐⊺bvec𝓡\mu^{*}\approx\frac{\bm{\omega}^{\intercal}\mathbf{B}_{1,J}{\bm{\mathcal{Q}}}_{\bm{\mathcal{A}}}^{\intercal}\mathrm{bvec}\{\bm{\mathcal{R}}\}}{2(\bm{\phi}^{\intercal}\mathbf{B}_{0,J}+\bm{\omega}^{\intercal}\mathbf{B}_{2,J}){\bm{\mathcal{Q}}}_{\bm{\mathcal{A}}}^{\intercal}\mathrm{bvec}\{\bm{\mathcal{R}}\}}. (37)

Note that, when no model-poisoning attack occurs, i.e., 𝝎=0𝝎0\bm{\omega}=0, the numerator on the RHS of (37) becomes zero, leading to μ∗=0superscript𝜇0\mu^{*}=0.

IV Simulation Results

To verify our theoretical findings, we conduct several numerical experiments. We also compare the performance of the PSO-Fed algorithm with that of the Online-Fed, SignSGD, CS-Fed, and QS-Fed algorithms within a federated network comprising K=50𝐾50K=50 or 100100100 clients and a model parameter vector of size D=5𝐷5D=5. Each client possesses non-IID data vectors 𝐱k,nsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑛\mathbf{x}_{k,n} and their associated response values yk,nsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑛y_{k,n}, which are interconnected as per (1) with model parameter vector 𝐰=1D​[1,⋯,1]⊺∈ℝD𝐰1𝐷superscript1⋯1⊺superscriptℝ𝐷\mathbf{w}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{D}}[1,\cdots,1]^{\intercal}\in\mathbb{R}^{D}. Each entry of 𝐱k,nsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑛\mathbf{x}_{k,n} for each client k𝑘k is drawn from a zero-mean Gaussian distribution with variance ςk2superscriptsubscript𝜍𝑘2\varsigma_{k}^{2}, where ςk2superscriptsubscript𝜍𝑘2\varsigma_{k}^{2} itself is sampled from a uniform distribution between 0.20.20.2 and 1.21.21.2, denoted as 𝒰​(0.2,1.2)𝒰0.21.2\mathcal{U}(0.2,1.2). In addition, the observation noise νk,nsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑛\nu_{k,n} is zero-mean IID Gaussian with variance σνk2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝜈𝑘2\sigma_{\nu_{k}}^{2} drawn from 𝒰​(0.005,0.025)𝒰0.0050.025\mathcal{U}(0.005,0.025). In the conducted experiments, only M=1𝑀1M=1 entry of the model parameter vector is shared per iteration, unless specified differently.

We evaluate the performance of the considered algorithms on the server’s side by employing a test dataset consisting of Nt=50subscript𝑁𝑡50N_{t}=50 instances {𝐗˘,𝐲˘}˘𝐗˘𝐲\{\breve{\mathbf{X}},\breve{\mathbf{y}}\} and calculating the test MSE at the server as

1Nt​‖𝐲˘−𝐗˘⊺​𝐰n‖22.1subscript𝑁𝑡subscriptsuperscriptnorm˘𝐲superscript˘𝐗⊺subscript𝐰𝑛22\displaystyle\frac{1}{N_{t}}\ \|\breve{\mathbf{y}}-\breve{\mathbf{X}}^{\intercal}\mathbf{w}_{n}\|^{2}_{2}. (38)

We also evaluate the performance of PSO-Fed on the client side using (4a) and calculating the network-wide average steady-state MSE as

1K​∑k=1Klimn→∞ϵk,n2.1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript→𝑛superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘𝑛2\displaystyle\frac{1}{K}\ \sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\epsilon_{k,n}^{2}. (39)

In our first experiment, we examine the effect of different numbers of Byzantine clients |𝒮B|subscript𝒮𝐵|\mathcal{S}_{B}| on the steady-state test MSE for PSO-Fed, Online-Fed, SignSGD, CS-Fed, and QS-Fed. In this experiment, We have K=100𝐾100K=100 clients. In every iteration n𝑛n, the server randomly selects a set of |𝒮n|=5subscript𝒮𝑛5|\mathcal{S}_{n}|=5 clients to participate in FL, with each client having an equal probability of being selected. In addition, all Byzantine clients are characterized by model-poisoning noise variance of σB2=0.25superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵20.25\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.25 and attack probability of pa=1subscript𝑝𝑎1p_{a}=1. In each iteration, we allocate the same communication budget to all algorithms. Therefore, to allow all algorithms converge to their lowest steady-state MSD within 300030003000 iterations, we set μ=0.15𝜇0.15\mu=0.15 for PSO-Fed, Online-Fed, CS-Fed and QS-Fed, and μ=0.08𝜇0.08\mu=0.08 for SignSGD at all clients. According to (30), the maximum stepsize ensuring the mean-square convergence of PSO-Fed in this experiment is μm​a​x=0.245subscript𝜇𝑚𝑎𝑥0.245\mu_{max}=0.245. The results displayed in Fig. 1 indicate that PSO-Fed outperforms the existing algorithms across all considered number of Byzantine clients. Notably, Online-Fed and PSO-Fed perform similarly when there is no Byzantine client or poisoning attack (i.e., σB2=0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵20\sigma_{B}^{2}=0). However, the performance of Online-Fed deteriorates more than PSO-Fed as the number of Byzantine clients increases. While CS-Fed performs closely to PSO-Fed in our experiment, it is important to note that the computational complexity of CS-Fed exceeds that of PSO-Fed.

In our second experiment, we examine the impact of the number of shared entries, M𝑀M, on the steady-state test MSE of PSO-Fed. We simulate PSO-Fed with K=50𝐾50K=50 clients, D=5𝐷5D=5, |𝒮B|∈{5,15}subscript𝒮𝐵515|\mathcal{S}_{B}|\in\{5,15\} Byzantine clients, attack strength σB2=0.5superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵20.5\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.5, and attack probability pa=0.2subscript𝑝𝑎0.2p_{a}=0.2. The results are shown in Fig. 3. We observe that increasing M𝑀M leads to higher steady-state test MSE. In addition, PSO-Fed exhibits greater resilience to model-poisoning attacks compared to Online-Fed, without incurring any extra computational or communication burden on the clients. This experiment corroborates our theoretical findings discussed in section III-C.

In our third experiment, we investigate the effect of varying the attack strength σB2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵2\sigma_{B}^{2} on the network-wide average steady state MSE. We simulate PSO-Fed with K=50𝐾50K=50 clients, D=5𝐷5D=5, |𝒮B|∈{5,15}subscript𝒮𝐵515|\mathcal{S}_{B}|\in\{5,15\} Byzantine clients, attack strength σB2∈{0,0.25,0.5,0.75,1}superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵200.250.50.751\sigma_{B}^{2}\in\{0,0.25,0.5,0.75,1\}, and attack probability pa=0.2subscript𝑝𝑎0.2p_{a}=0.2. The server randomly selects 555 clients in each iteration. The results depicted in Fig.2 align closely with our theoretical predictions. We notice an upward trend in the network-wide average steady-state MSE as the attack strength or the number of Byzantine clients increases. In addition, the presence of |𝒮B|=α1subscript𝒮𝐵subscript𝛼1|\mathcal{S}_{B}|=\alpha_{1} Byzantine clients with an attack strength of σB2=β1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵2subscript𝛽1\sigma_{B}^{2}=\beta_{1} results in the same MSE as having |𝒮B|=α2subscript𝒮𝐵subscript𝛼2|\mathcal{S}_{B}|=\alpha_{2} Byzantine clients with an attack strength σB2=β2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵2subscript𝛽2\sigma_{B}^{2}=\beta_{2}, provided that the condition α1​β1=α2​β2subscript𝛼1subscript𝛽1subscript𝛼2subscript𝛽2\alpha_{1}\beta_{1}=\alpha_{2}\beta_{2} is met.

In our fourth experiment, we explore how the attack probability pasubscript𝑝𝑎p_{a} influences the steady-state test MSE of PSO-Fed, considering different numbers of shared entries M∈{1,5}𝑀15M\in\{1,5\}, with the number of Byzantine clients set to |𝒮B|=5subscript𝒮𝐵5|\mathcal{S}_{B}|=5 and attack strength to σB2=0.25superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵20.25\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.25. The results, presented in Fig. 5, align with observations from the previous experiment, showing that an increase in the attack probability leads to a higher MSE. Moreover, partial sharing (i.e., when M<D𝑀𝐷M<D) enhances the resilience against model-poisoning attacks as elaborated upon in section III-C.

In our fifth experiment, we investigate the impact of attack probability pasubscript𝑝𝑎p_{a} on the steady-state test MSE of PSO-Fed, considering different numbers of Byzantine clients |𝒮B|∈{5,15}subscript𝒮𝐵515|\mathcal{S}_{B}|\in\{5,15\} and setting the attack strength as σB2=0.25superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵20.25\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.25. The results shown in Fig. 4 indicate that increasing the attack probability increases the steady-state MSE.

In our sixth experiment, we evaluate the performance of PSO-Fed using different stepsize values and Byzantine client numbers in the presence or absence of model-poisoning attacks. We simulate PSO-Fed with K=50𝐾50K=50 clients, D=5𝐷5D=5, attack strength σB2=0.25superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵20.25\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.25, attack probability pa=0.25subscript𝑝𝑎0.25p_{a}=0.25. The server randomly selects 555 clients in each iteration. The results illustrated in Fig. 6, show that with no model-poisoning attack (|𝒮B|=0subscript𝒮𝐵0|\mathcal{S}_{B}|=0), the larger the stepsize μ𝜇\mu, the worse PSO-Fed performs, a trend consistent with gradient descent optimization methods. However, with model-poisoning attacks (|𝒮B|>0subscript𝒮𝐵0|\mathcal{S}_{B}|>0), the performance first improves with an increase in μ𝜇\mu, then deteriorates when μ𝜇\mu grows larger. This observation confirms the existence of an optimal stepsize μ∗superscript𝜇\mu^{*} that ensures the best performance of PSO-Fed under model-poisoning attacks. By calculating the optimal stepsize using (37), we determine μ∗≈0.03superscript𝜇0.03\mu^{*}\approx 0.03, which corresponds to the experimental results.

In our seventh experiment, we analyze the performance of PSO-Fed using different stepsizes in the presence or absence of model-poisoning attacks, considering different attack strengths σB2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵2\sigma_{B}^{2}. We simulate PSO-Fed with K=50𝐾50K=50 clients, D=5𝐷5D=5, |𝒮B|=5subscript𝒮𝐵5|\mathcal{S}_{B}|=5 Byzantine clients, and attack probability of pa=0.25subscript𝑝𝑎0.25p_{a}=0.25. The server randomly selects 555 clients in each iteration. The results, presented in Fig. 7, echo the observations from the previous experiment: without a poisoning attack (σB2=0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵20\sigma_{B}^{2}=0), PSO-Fed’s performance decreases as the stepsize μ𝜇\mu increases. Conversely, with model-poisoning attacks (σB2>0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵20\sigma_{B}^{2}>0), performance initially improves with an increase in μ𝜇\mu but begins to decline as μ𝜇\mu is further increased. This pattern confirms the existence of an optimal stepsize μ∗superscript𝜇\mu^{*} for scenarios with model-poisoning attacks. Using (37) to estimate the optimal stepsize, we find μ∗≈0.03superscript𝜇0.03\mu^{*}\approx 0.03, corresponding to the experiment’s findings. This experiment also reinforces our conclusion following the third experiment that identical attack properties result in the same MSE.

In our eighth experiment, we investigate the impact of the commonly-adopted small stepsize approximation (SSA) on predicting the performance of PSO-Fed in the presence or absence of model-poisoning attacks. Specifically, we assume that higher orders of μ𝜇\mu are negligible when computing 𝓕𝓕{\bm{\mathcal{F}}} via (18). We then compare the simulated network-wide average MSE of PSO-Fed with the corresponding theoretical predictions with or without SSA. We simulate PSO-Fed with K=50𝐾50K=50 clients, D=5𝐷5D=5, attack probability pa=0.25subscript𝑝𝑎0.25p_{a}=0.25, attack strength σB2=0.5superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐵20.5\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.5, and numbers of Byzantine clients |𝒮B|∈{0,10}subscript𝒮𝐵010|\mathcal{S}_{B}|\in\{0,10\}. The server randomly selects 555 clients in each iteration. The results in Fig. 8 reveal that, when μ𝜇\mu is sufficiently small, SSA does not hinder the accurate prediction of steady-state MSE even without the knowledge of the 444th moment of the input vector, 𝓗𝓗\bm{\mathcal{H}}. However, as the stepsize increases, discrepancies arise in both scenarios, with and without model-poisoning attacks, diverging from the ideal case.

In our final experiment, we investigate the effect of partial sharing on different terms of MSE (III-C), namely, ℰ𝝎subscriptℰ𝝎\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}} and ℰϕsubscriptℰbold-italic-ϕ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}}, in the presence of model-poisoning attacks. We compute both terms using the same setup as in our second experiment. The results depicted in Fig. 9 show that decreasing the number of shared parameters considerably lowers ℰ𝝎subscriptℰ𝝎\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}}, significantly mitigating the impact of model-poisoning attacks. However, sharing fewer entries increases ℰϕsubscriptℰbold-italic-ϕ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}}. Still, the benefits of partial sharing in reducing ℰ𝝎subscriptℰ𝝎\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}} are more substantial, leading to reduced MSE. Note that ℰϕsubscriptℰbold-italic-ϕ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}} remains unchanged across both considered cases, as it depends solely on scheduling and data noise. Finally, this experiment corroborates our theoretical findings and confirms our assertions regarding the effect of partial sharing on ℰ𝝎subscriptℰ𝝎\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}} and ℰϕsubscriptℰbold-italic-ϕ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}}, as discussed at the end of section III-C.

V Conclusion

We conducted a theoretical analysis of the recently proposed PSO-Fed algorithm to examine its resilience to model-poisoning (Byzantine) attacks imparted by partial sharing. In our analysis, we considered a linear regression task with the local objective function of each client defined as an empirical risk. We showed that, even under Byzantine attacks, PSO-Fed converges in both mean and mean-square senses, given an appropriate choice of stepsize. More importantly, we showed that, in the presence of Byzantine clients, the steady-state MSE of PSO-Fed is significantly smaller than that of the Online-Fed algorithm, which does not feature partial sharing. Our theoretical analysis also uncovered the existence of a non-trivial optimal stepsize for PSO-Fed in the presence of model-poisoning attacks The simulation results corroborated our theoretical findings regarding PSO-Fed’s effectiveness against Byzantine attacks as well as the accuracy of the theoretically predicted values of its steady-state MSE and optimal stepsize.

where each entry of 𝔼​[𝐱k,n⊗𝐱k,n]∈ℝD×D𝔼delimited-[]tensor-productsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑛subscript𝐱𝑘𝑛superscriptℝ𝐷𝐷\mathbb{E}[{\mathbf{x}}_{k,n}\otimes{\mathbf{x}}_{k,n}]\in\mathbb{R}^{D\times D} can be computed by utilizing the Isserlis’ theorem [43] as

{𝔼​[xk,l,n2]=σl​l2∀k,l,n𝔼​[xk,l,n​xk,m,n]=σl​mif l≠m.cases𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑙𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙𝑙2for-all𝑘𝑙𝑛𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑥𝑘𝑙𝑛subscript𝑥𝑘𝑚𝑛subscript𝜎𝑙𝑚if l≠m\begin{cases}\mathbb{E}[{x}_{k,l,n}^{2}]=\sigma_{ll}^{2}&\forall k,l,n\\ \mathbb{E}[{x}_{k,l,n}{x}_{k,m,n}]=\sigma_{lm}&\text{if $l\neq m$}.\end{cases} (49)

Given that the entries of 𝐱i,nsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑛{\mathbf{x}}_{i,n} are independent of each other, i.e., σl​m=0subscript𝜎𝑙𝑚0\sigma_{lm}=0 and assuming an identical variance among all entries of 𝐱i,nsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑛{\mathbf{x}}_{i,n}, i.e., σl​l=σksubscript𝜎𝑙𝑙subscript𝜎𝑘\sigma_{ll}=\sigma_{k}, we can write (49) as

{𝔼​[xk,l,n2]=σk2∀k,l,n𝔼​[xk,l,n​xk,m,n]=0if l≠m.cases𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑙𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2for-all𝑘𝑙𝑛𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑥𝑘𝑙𝑛subscript𝑥𝑘𝑚𝑛0if l≠m\begin{cases}\mathbb{E}[{x}_{k,l,n}^{2}]=\sigma_{k}^{2}&\forall k,l,n\\ \mathbb{E}[{x}_{k,l,n}{x}_{k,m,n}]=0&\text{if $l\neq m$}.\end{cases} (50)
